DT Article
TI The "Digne ammonite slab" ("Reserve Naturelle Geologique de
   Haute-Provence", France). Palaeontological and sedimentological study of
   a fossiliferous locality of patrimonial significance.
FT La "Dalle a ammonites de Digne" (Reserve Naturelle Geologique de
   Haute-Provence, France). Etude d'un site fossilifere d'importance
   patrimoniale.
AU Dommergues, Jean-Louis (Jean-Louis.Dommergues@u-bourgogne.fr) 
   Guiomar, Myette
SO Revue de Paleobiologie
VL 30
IS 1
PS 261-293
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA French
U1 0
U2 3
AB The "Digne ammonite slab" is a spectacular fossiliferous feature of both
   scientific and patrimonial significance. The entire outcrop is protected
   by the " Reserve Naturelle Geologique de Haute-Provence " RNGHP. This
   remarkable slab, measuring about 320 m2, is the chief element in the
   outcrop. It exhibits more than 1550 cephalopods (many ammonites but also
   some nautilids) and bears a less obtrusive but diversified benthic
   fauna, mainly composed of epibenthic bivalves. Conversely, the striking
   ammonite fauna is, in taxonomic terms, rather monotonous with numerous
   Arietitidae (Coroniceras) but only sparse Schlotheimiidae
   (Angulaticeras). In fact the ammonite fauna is chiefly composed of a
   single highly dominant species, Coroniceras multicostatum (J. de C.
   Sowerby, 1824) of which the abundant large specimens, sometime more than
   50 cm in diameter, are the most obvious and famous component of the
   "Dalle". This work is a monograph dedicated to the "Digne ammonite
   slab", in which palaeontological, palaeobiogeographical,
   palaeoecological, stratigraphical and sedimentological aspects are all
   considered. Although no specimens can deliberately be extracted from
   this highly protected locality, a morphometric study grounded in a
   significant set of data collected in situ allows the intraspecific
   variability of Coroniceras multicostatum to be explored. The results of
   this analysis suggest a short deposit duration, in geological terms, for
   the "Digne ammonite slab" fauna. As an experiment, the "Dalle" was
   recently 3D scanned and the palaeontological iconography is now composed
   both of computer-generated images of in situ specimens and of
   photographs of exemplars housed in the RNGHP collections.
C1 Dommergues, Jean-Louis; Centre des Sciences de la Terre et de
   l'Environnement, Universite de Bourgogne, CNRS/uB, UMR 5561,
   Biogeosciences Dijon, 6 Boulevard Gabriel, F-21000 Dijon, France,
   France.
EM Jean-Louis.Dommergues@u-bourgogne.fr
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Paleontology
SN 0253-6730
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Ecology; Zoogeography; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Ammonoidea [Ecology / Palaeoecology / systematics] [Fossil assemblages /
   / ] [Zoogeography / Palaeobiogeography / ] [France / Haute-Provence,
   Digne / stratigraphical distribution] [Jurassic / Lower Jurassic / ].

DT Article
TI Additional to the Maastrichtian foraminifera of the Middle East.
AU Anan, Haidar Salim (profanan@gmail.com) 
SO Revue de Paleobiologie
VL 30
IS 1
PS 295-311
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Additional ten diagnostic Maastrichtian foraminiferal species have been
   recorded and illustrated for the first time from three sections in the
   Middle East. two out of these three sections are from north and central
   Egypt : Wadi Ed Dakhl section (west Gulf of Suez) and Duwi section
   (Qusseir area at west Red Sea coast), respectively. the third one is
   Qarn El Barr section (Dhayd area) from north United Arab Emirates (UAE).
   two out of the ten species are planktic : Plummerita hantkeninoides
   (from Duwi section) and Abathomphalus mayaroensis (from Wadi Ed Dakhl
   section). Six species are small benthic : Spiroplectinella laevis,
   Neoflabellina reticulata, Bolivinoides draco, Bolivinoides giganteus,
   Sitella cushmani, Gyroidinoides globosa (from Wadi Ed Dakhl section).
   Another small benthic species Euloxsostomum mouradi n. sp. is described
   and added to these species from the Maastrichtian rocks of Wadi Ed Dakhl
   section. The small benthic species Clavulinoides concavus and another
   large foraminiferal species Siderolites calcitrapoides are recorded and
   illustrated from Qarn El Barr section. paleontology, stratigraphy,
   paleogeography and paleoenvironmental remarks of these species are
   presented.

   University-Gaza, Gaza P.O. Box 1277, Palestine, Israel, Israel.

PT J
AN ZOOR14802013516
DT Article
TI Early Albian ammonites from Central Tunisia and adjacent areas of
   Algeria.
AU Latil, Jean-Louis (g.r.e.g.b@wanadoo.fr) 
SO Revue de Paleobiologie
VL 30
IS 1
PS 321-429
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Nine sections were measured and studied in the Tadjerouine area (Central
   Tunisia), providing an abundant paleontological material. The historical
   collections of Pervinquiere (1907) from Central Tunisia, Dubourdieu
   (Dubourdieu, 1949, 1953 and 1956 ; Breistroffer, 1953a ; Sornay, 1955)
   and Masse (Masse&Thieuloy, 1979) for the Ouenza area (Algeria) are
   revised and integrated to the paleontological and biostratigraphical
   study. A new regional biozonation on the basis of the ammonites is
   proposed for the Early Albian of Central Tunisia, revealing an almost
   complete and continuous succession from the base of the Albian to its
   top. Unfortunately, due to the lack of paleontological datas, the
   Aptian-Albian boundary cannot be defined. The ammonite succession allows
   precise correlations with the ammonite biozonation established in
   western Europe (Owen, 1999, 2002 ; Kennedy et al., 2000). The Hameima
   section (HMA) in Jebel Hameima, is herein considered as a regional
   reference which is completed by the Harraba section (HB) in Jebel
   Harraba for the lower part and Bou El Haneche section (BEH) in Jebel Bou
   El Haneche for the upper part. This biostratigraphical sequence is the
   most complete for the Early Albian of the South tethyan margins. An
   Earliest Albian detailed ammonite succession is recognized for the first
   time on the South Tethyan Margins. Three new ammonite genera are herein
   described : Hameimaceras gen. nov., Buloticeras gen. nov. and
   Mellegueiceras nov. gen. Nine species are new : Hameimaceras zghalae
   gen. nov., sp. nov. ; Pseudhelicoceras dubourdieui sp. nov. ;
   Douvilleiceras sp. nov. ? ; Mellegueiceras chihaouiae nov. gen., nov.
   sp. ; Mellegueiceras hameimaensis nov. gen., nov. sp. ; Mellegueiceras
   minutus nov. gen., nov. sp. ; Mellegueiceras jaillardi nov. gen.,
   nov.sp. ; 'Hypacanthoplites' roberti sp. nov. and 'Hypacanthoplites'
   buloti sp. nov. These species all come from the earliest part of the
   Early Albian, revealing a high level of ammonite endemism on the central
   Tunisian platform. This endemism strongly declines with the Early Albian
   transgression.
C1 Latil, Jean-Louis; Le Maupas, F-05300 Lazer, France, France.

   Geological time periods; Mesozoic

DT Article
TI Albian-Cenomanian ammonites from Sumbe area (Kwanza Basin, Angola).
FT Les ammonites de la limite Albien - Cenomanien dans la region de Sumbe
   (Bassin de la Kwanza, Angola).
AU Meister, Christian (christian.meister@ville-ge.ch) 
   Buta, Andre
   David, Bruno
   Tavares, Tatiana
SO Revue de Paleobiologie
VL 30
IS 2
PS 685-781
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB An original fauna of large sized ammonite is described for the Angolan
   Cretaceous (Upper Albian [long dash] Lower Cenomanian) in the Sumbe
   area. The stage boundary is precisely stated by the presence of
   Mortoniceras (Subschloenbachia) aff. perinflatum (SPATH), Arestoceras
   goliath (HAAS), Mariella (Mariella) gr. bergeri (BRONGNIART) for the
   topmost Albian and of Mariella (Mariella) gr. oehlerti (PERVINQUIERE),
   Mariella (Mariella) aff. gallienii (BOULE, LEMOINE&THEVENIN) with
   Sharpeiceras group (S. florencae SPATH et de Sharpeiceras aff.
   schlneteri HYATT) for the basal Cenomanian. A. goliath (HAAS) species,
   seen in the literature as a nomen dubhon, is here rehabilitated and
   considered as an endemic ammonite from Angola, very common in the Sumbe
   area. The biostratigraphical framework is correlated with the standard
   zonation of West Europe and with those of North America and North
   Africa.

PT J
AN ZOOR14803025190
DT Article
TI On the identity of Coleophora pyrrhulipennella Zeller, 1839 and
   description of Coleophora pulchripennella Baldizzone n. sp.
   (Lepidoptera, Coleophoridae).
FT Sulla identita di Coleophora pyrrhulipennella Zeller, 1839 e descrizione
   di Coleophora pulchripennella Baldizzone n. sp. (Lepidoptera,
   Coleophoridae). Contribuzioni alla conoscenza dei Coleophoridae. CXXIV.
AU Baldizzone, Giorgio (giorgiobaldizzone@tin.it) 
   Landry, Jean-Francois
SO Rivista Piemontese di Storia Naturale
VL 32
PS 111-134
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB This work is devoted to the description of Coleophora pulchripennella,
   n. sp., a species with a predominantly Mediterranean distribution linked
   to its larval host plant, Erica arborea. It was previously confused with
   C. pyrrhulipennella Zeller, 1839, whose larvae feed on other species of
   Erica and on Calluna vulgaris. The two species can be distinguished by
   their habitus and marked differences in the male and female genitalia.
   DNA barcodes sequences showed a 1.8% interspecific difference between C.
   pulchripennella and C. pyrrhulipennella, that correlates well with
   morphological differences.
C1 Baldizzone, Giorgio; via Manzoni 24, 14100 Asti, Italy, Italy.
EM giorgiobaldizzone@tin.it
SC Zoology
SN 1121-1423
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Africa; Eurasia; Europe; Greece
DE Coleophora pulchripennella [Tunisia /  / New species] [Turkey /  / ]
   [Croatia /  / ] [France /  / ] [Greece /  / ] [Crete /  / ] [Italy /  /
   ] [Malta /  / ] [Spain /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Gelechioidea, Coleophoridae
OR Coleophora pulchripennella - Baldizzone 2011 (Coleophoridae): [Sp nov,
   Italy, P. 115]. 
   Coleophora pyrrhulipennella - Zeller 1839 (Coleophoridae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 114]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14803025190
DA 2020-09-17

   Sales 188, 10022 Carmagnola, Italy, Italy.

DT Article
TI MORPHOMETRY OF STRIPED TREE FROGS, Polypedates leucomystax (GRAVENHORST,
   1829) FROM INDONESIA WITH DESCRIPTION OF A NEW SPECIES.
AU Riyanto, Awal (awal_lizards@yahoo.com) 
   Mumpuni
   McGuire, Jimmy A.
SO Russian Journal of Herpetology
VL 18
IS 1
PS 29-35
PD January-March 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB We examined patterns of geographic variation within Polypedates
   leucomystax using multivariate statistical analyzes of 14 morphological
   characters measured from 146 specimens obtained from Sumatra, Java,
   Kalimantan, and Sulawesi. Discriminant analysis revealed ten
   morphological characters and found that the Sulawesi population is
   morphologically distinct from all others considered. Following the
   Evolutionary Species Concept, we describe the Sulawesi population as a
   new species in P. leucomystax species complex.
C1 Riyanto, Awal; Indonesian Inst Sci LIPI, Biol Res Ctr, Widyasatwaloka
   Bldg,Jl Raya Jakarta Bogor Km 46, Cibinong, Indonesia, Indonesia.

DT Article
TI Rafetus vietnamensis LE, LE, TRAN, PHAN, PHAN, TRAN, PHAM, NGUYEN, NONG,
   PHAN, DINH, TRUONG AND HA, 2010 - ANOTHER INVALID NAME FOR AN INVALID
   SPECIES OF SOFTSHELL TURTLE (REPTILIA: TESTUDINES: TRIONYCHIDAE).
AU Farkas, Balazs (farkasbalazs@yahoo.com) 
   Le, Minh Duc
   Nguyen, Truong Quang
SO Russian Journal of Herpetology
VL 18
IS 1
PS 65-72
PD January-March 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The description of Rafetus vietnamensis Le et al., 2010 is reviewed. As
   the name was based on the same type material as Rafetus leloii Ha, 2000,
   we declare R. vietnamensis an objective synonym of R. leloii.
   Simultaneously, no characteristics presented by Le et al. distinguish
   their R. vietnamensis from Rafetus swinhoei (Gray, 1873), which confirms
   our view that they constitute the same biological entity.
C1 Farkas, Balazs; Bercsenyi U 21, Gyuro, Hungary, Hungary.
EM farkasbalazs@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 1026-2296
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Anapsida, Testudines,
   Cryptodira, Trionychidae
OR Rafetus leloii - Ha 2000 (Trionychidae): [Junior synonym, Of Rafetus
   swinhoei (Gray 1873), p. 70; Syn nov, Rafetus vietnamensis Le et al
   2010, p. 70]. 
   Rafetus swinhoei - (Gray 1873) (Trionychidae): [Senior synonym, Of
   Rafetus leloii Ha 2000, p. 70].

DT Article
TI Two new species of Steinernema Travassos, 1927 with short infective
   juveniles from Nepal.
AU Khatri-Chhetri, Hari Bahadur (kchari2002@yahoo.co.uk) 
   Waeyenberge, Lieven
   Spiridonov, Sergei
   Manandhar, Hira Kaji
   Moens, Maurice
SO Russian Journal of Nematology
VL 19
IS 1
PS 53-74
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB During a survey conducted in 2007 in Nepal, two new species of
   entomopathogenic nematodes, Steinernema nepalense sp. n. and Steinernema
   surkhetense sp. n. were recovered from soil samples collected in
   Itahari, Sunsari and Birendranagar, Surkhet, respectively. The infective
   juveniles of S. nepalense sp. n. are recognised by body length 479
   (424-513) gm, pharynx length 38 (32-46) [mu]m, tail length 53 (48-61)
   [mu]m, H% = 63 (52-71) and E% = 71 (58-87). The lateral field pattern is
   2, 7, 8, 6, 5, 4, 2. The males have slender, well curved yellowish-brown
   spicules (71 (56-78) [mu]m) and 25 genital papillae. The infective
   juveniles of S. surkhetense sp. n. can be recognised by the body length
   averaging 415 (393-450) gm, pharynx length 32 (28-34) gm, H% = 57
   (44-73) and E% = 72 (54-84). The lateral field pattern is 2, 8, 7, 5, 2.
   The males have well curved brownish spicules (70 (58-78) gm) with thin
   velum and 23/25 genital papillae. The analysis of ITS-rDNA sequences
   places both species in the 'carpocapsae-scapteriscitami' group.
C1 Khatri-Chhetri, Hari Bahadur; District Agriculture Development Office,
   Dailekh, Department of Agriculture, Nepal, Nepal.
EM kchari2002@yahoo.co.uk
RI Spiridonov, Sergei E./A-5383-2016
OI Spiridonov, Sergei E./0000-0001-6657-0418

SN 0869-6918
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Parasites diseases and
   disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Achroia grisella; Bombyx mori; Corcyra cephalonica; Galleria mellonella
   [Nematode parasites / Steinernema / Host preference]. 
   Steinernema [Phylogeny /  / host preference] [Lepidopteran hosts /
   Achroia grisella / ] [ / Bombyx mori / ] [ / Corcyra cephalonica / ] [ /
   Galleria mellonella / ]. 
   Steinernema nepalense; Steinernema surkhetense [Nepal /  / New species].

DT Article
TI Taxonomic note on Caraphractus (Hymenoptera: Mymaridae).
AU Triapitsyn, Serguei V. (serguei.triapitsyn@ucr.edu) 
SO Sahlbergia
VL 17
IS 2
PS 20-29
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Taxonomic notes on the Holarctic fairyfly genus Caraphractus Walker,
   1846 (Hymenoptera: Chalcidoidea: Mymaridae) and its only recognized
   species C. cinctus Walker, 1846 are given. Caraphractus flavicollis
   Hellen, 1974 (Finland) is synonymized under C. cinctus. A lectotype is
   designated for C. reductus Rimsky-Korsakov, 1920, also a synonym of C.
   cinctus. Caraphractus hazomanitrae Risbec, 1952 (Madagascar), for which
   a lectotype is designated, is transferred to Acmopolvnema Ogloblin, 1946
   as A. hazomanitrae (Risbec), syn. n. Camptoptera perineti (Risbec, 1952)
   (Madagascar, originally described as Stichothrix perineti) is
   synonymized under A. hazomanitrae.
C1 Triapitsyn, Serguei V.; Entomology Research Museum, Department of
   Entomology, University of California, Riverside, California 92521, USA,
   USA.
EM serguei.triapitsyn@ucr.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1237-3273

   Unavailable name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Caraphractus cinctus [Austria /  / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Proctotrupoidea, Mymaridae
OR Acmopolynema hazomanitrae - (Risbec 1952) (Mymaridae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Caraphractus, p. 26; Syn nov, Camptoptera perineti
   (Risbec 1952), p. 26]. 
   Anaphes dytiscidarum - Rimsky-Korsakov 1920 (Mymaridae): [Nomen nudum,
   P. 26]. 
   Caraphractus - Walker 1846 (Mymaridae): [Systematics, P. 20]. 
   Caraphractus cinctus - Walker 1846 (Mymaridae): [Syn nov, Caraphractus
   flavicollis Hellen 1974, p. 24; New record]. 
   Caraphractus hazomanitrae - Risbec 1952 (Mymaridae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 26; Referred to, Acmopolynema, p. 26]. 
   Caraphractus reductus - Rimsky-Korsakov 1920 (Mymaridae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 24].

TI A report on the recent worm slit shell Tenagodus obtusiformis Martin
   1905 with the description of two new species from western Indonesian
   waters.
AU Dharma, Bunjamin (bdharma@dnet.net.id) 
SO Schriften zur Malakozoologie aus dem Haus der Natur-Cismar
VL 26
PS 15-26
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Recent specimens of the fossil worm slit shell species Tenagodus
   obtusiformis MARTIN 1905 from the family Siliquariidae ANTON 1838,
   subfamily Siliquariinae ANTON 1838 are examined. Two new recent species
   are described: A species with the elevated operculum of the genus
   Tenagodus GIETTARD 1770 is named Tenagodus sundaensis n. sp., and
   another one with the flattened operculum of genus Petalopoma
   SCHIAPARELLI 2002 is named Petalopoma indoensis n. sp. Both species and
   recent specimens of Tenagodus obtusiformis MARTIN 1905 were collected
   from several localities in the western area of Indonesian waters.

DT Article
TI New record of gastropods in the Yacoraite Formation
   (Maastrichtian-Daniano) from the Cordillera Oriental de Jujuy,
   Argentina. Systematic bioestratigraphy and geological correlation.
FT Nuevo registro de gasteropodos en la Formation Yacoraite
   (Maastrichtiano-Daniano) Cordillera Oriental de Jujuy, Argentina.
   Sistematica, bioestratigrafia y correlation geologica.
AU Console Gonella, Carlos A. (carlos_console@yahoo.com.ar) 
SO Serie Correlacion Geologica
VL 27
PS 45-64
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB We present a new record of gastropods recovered in limestones of the
   Yacoraite Formation (Maastrichtian-Danian) in Jueya environs, Cordillera
   Oriental of Jujuy, Argentina. Has been identified 91 fossils,
   distributed in the genera: Brachycerithium Bonarelli 1921; Bonarelliella
   n. gen. and Percossnuranella n. gen. Has been defined the species
   Brachycenthium erolutum Bonarelli 1921; Brathycerithium minus Bonarelli
   1921; Brathypcerithium ferugloi? Bonarelli 1921; Bonarelliella jueyai
   sp. nov; Bonariella ameghinorum Bonarelli 1927 (Console Gonella nov.
   comb.); Bonarelliella brackehuschii sp. nov; Bonarlliella multicosta
   Bonarelli 1927 (Console Gonella nov. comb.) and Percossmannella
   steinmannii sp. nov. As result of the research, the affinities and
   bioestratigraphic range of this fauna are still open to highest levels.

DT Article
TI A Revision of the Nearctic Species of the Genus Trixoscelis Rondani
   (Diptera: Heleomyzidae: Trixoscelidinae).
AU Foster, George A. (64@hotmail.com) 
   Mathis, Wayne N.
SO Smithsonian Contributions to Zoology
VL 637
PS 1-129
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Foster, George A., and Wayne N. Mathis. A Revision of the Nearctic
   Species of the Genus Trixoscelis Rondani (Diptera: Heleomyzidae:
   Trixoscelidinae). Smithsonian Contributions to Zoology, number 637, viii
   + 128 pages, 187 igures, 1 table, 2011.[long dash]The Nearctic species
   of the genus Trixoscelis Rondani are revised. Thirteen new species are
   described, seven new combinations and three new synonyms are proposed,
   and three species groups are character- ized. Keys to the 38 known
   species are provided. Diagnoses, detailed distributional data for the
   species of the genus, notes on the biology, and illustrations
   (photographs and drawings) are included to assist species identiication.
   A phylogenetic analysis was performed to test the monophyly of the genus
   Trixoscelis and the included species groups. The ingroup includes a
   total of 38 exemplar species. Outgroup sampling includes the following
   exemplar gen- era: Neossos, Waterhousea, Fenwickia, Aneuria, and Xenura.
   Analyses, including implied weighting, recovered a monophyletic
   Trixoscelis and species groups if the Mongolian genus Paratrixoscelis is
   included within Trixoscelis.
C1 Foster, George A.; Department of Entomology, P.O. Box 37012, MRC 169,
   Smithsonian Institution, Washington DC 20012-70121, USA, USA.

PT J
AN ZOOR14707051597
DT Article
TI A Revision of the Genus Aulacigaster Macquart (Diptera:
   Aulacigastridae).
AU Rung, Alessandra
   Mathis, Wayne N. (mathisw@si.edu) 
SO Smithsonian Contributions to Zoology
VL 633
PS 1-129
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The world's described species of the genus Aulacigaster Macquart, now
   numbering 55, are revised. New species from the Afrotropical (2
   species), Neotropical (37 species), and Oriental Regions (2 species) are
   described, and the genus is divided into seven species groups, of which
   six are Neotropical. Keys to the species groups and to the known species
   occurring in the Afrotropical, Nearctic, Neotropical, Palearctic, and
   Oriental Regions are provided. Diagnoses, detailed distributional data
   for species of the genus, notes on the biology, and illustrations
   (photographs and drawings) are included to facilitate species
   identification. A phylo- genetic analysis was performed to test the
   monophyly of the genus Aulacigaster and to discover relationships
   between included species, hence indicating the monophyly of the species
   groups. The ingroup includes a total of 24 exemplar congeners. Outgroup
   sampling includes exemplars from the putative sister group,
   Curiosimusca. Analyses with and without successive weighting recovered a
   monophyletic Aulacigaster and indicated clades within the genus.
C1 Mathis, Wayne N.; Smithsonian Inst, Natl Museum Nat Hist, POB 37012,NHB
   CE-619,MRC 169, Washington, DC, USA, USA.
EM mathisw@si.edu

   Eurasia; Asia; India; Central America; West Indies; South America

PT J
AN ZOOR14707049437
DT Article
TI The Beach Flies (Diptera: Canacidae) of the Madeiran archipelago
   (Portugal), with description of a new species.
AU Munari, Lorenzo (lormun@iol.it) 
   Stuke, Jens Hermann
SO Societa Veneziana di Scienze Naturali Lavori
VL 36
PS 5-13
PD Gennaio 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A faunal review of the Canacidae of the Madeiran archipelago is
   proposed, including the description of a new species of Tethina Haliday,
   838 front Madeira Island. A key to species of canacid flies hitherto
   recorded from this archipelago is also given. The canacid fauna of these
   oceanic islands is characterized by colonizer species from the Iberian
   Peninsula and the Mediterranean basin, except for two putatively endemic
   species, Canace actites Mathis e Tahina carolae sp. nov.
C1 Munari, Lorenzo; Nat Hist Museum, Entomol Sect, S Croce 1730, Venice,
   Italy, Italy.
EM lormun@iol.it
SC Zoology
SN 0392-9450
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Oceanic
   islands; Atlantic Ocean islands
DE Canacidae [Madeira Islands /  / Key to genera & species] [ / Madeiran
   archipelago / Faunal list]. 
   Tethina carolae [Madeira Islands /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Tethinidae
OR Canacidae (Cyclorrhapha): [Key to genera, Madeira Islands, P. 7; Key to
   species, Madeira Islands, P. 7]. 
   Tethina carolae (Tethinidae): [Sp nov, Madeira Islands, P. 9].

DT Article
TI Philotelma ulianai sp. nov from Egypt (Insecta, Diptera, Ephydridae).
AU Raffone, Gianni (gianni_raffone@tin.it) 
SO Societa Veneziana di Scienze Naturali Lavori
VL 36
PS 15-17
PD Gennaio 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Philotelma ulianai sp.nov. from Egypt is described. The new species is
   related to P defictum day, 1833), and differs from it in having two
   supra-alar and one katepisternal setae (one supra-alar and two
   katepisternal in P defictum), the legs entirely yellow (brown in P
   (defectum), as well as for the morphology of the male terminalia.
C1 Raffone, Gianni; Museo Storia Nat, S Croce 1730, Venice, Italy, Italy.
EM gianni_raffone@tin.it
SC Zoology
SN 0392-9450
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Africa
DE Philotelma ulianai [Egypt /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Ephydridae
OR Philotelma ulianai (Ephydridae): [Sp nov, Egypt, P. 15].

AN ZOOR14707049439
DT Article
TI On some specimens of Wiedemannia Zetterstedt, 1838, with description of
   Wiedemannia (Philolutra) plavensis sp. nov (Insecta, Diptera,
   Empididae).
AU Raffone, Gianni (gianni_raffone@tin.it) 
SO Societa Veneziana di Scienze Naturali Lavori
VL 36
PS 19-22
PD Gennaio 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Wiedemannia (Phitolutra)plavensis sp.nov. from Piave river, Nervesa
   della Battaglia (Treviso Province, NE Italy) is described. The new
   species is related to Wiedemannia (Philolutra)fallaciosa (Loew, 1873)
   and differs from it for the number of notopleural setae (four in W
   plavensis, two in W laciosa), for the lack of anepisternal setae
   (presents in W.fallaciosa), as well as for the morphology of the male
   terminal in. In addition, a single specimen of Wiedemannia (Philolutra)
   sp., similar to W (Philolutra)fallaciosa (Loew, 1878) is reported. This
   specimen differs from W.fallaciosa for the lack of superior notopleural
   setae and for the colour of anepisternum and katepisternum. Being this
   specimen a female, its description is not given.
C1 Raffone, Gianni; Museo Storia Nat, S Croce 1730, Venice, Italy, Italy.
EM gianni_raffone@tin.it
SC Zoology
SN 0392-9450
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe
DE Wiedemannia (Philolutra) plavensis [Italy /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Orthorrhapha,
   Empididae

DT Article
TI Raniliformis bellini n. sp., a new raninid crab (Decapoda, Brachyura)
   from the Eocene of Chiampo Valley (Vicenza, NE Italy).
FT Raniliformis bellini n. sp., nuovo crostaceo Raninidae (Decapoda,
   Brachyura) dell'Eocene della Valle del Chiampo (Vicenza, Italia
   settentrionale).
AU De Angeli, Antonio (antonio.deangeli@alice.it) 
SO Societa Veneziana di Scienze Naturali Lavori
VL 36
PS 103-109
PD Gennaio 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Raniliformis bellini n. sp. (Crustacea, Decapoda, Brachyura, Raninidae)
   from the middle Eocene of "Albanello" quarry of Nogarole Vicentino
   (Vicenza, northern Italy) is described. The genus was already known for
   the Tertiary of the Lessini orientali Mountains with Raniliformis
   eocaenica (Beschin, Busulini, De Angeli & Tessier, 1988), R. ornata De
   Angeli & Beschin, 2007, and R. Rugosa De Angeli & Beschin, 2007. The new
   species is characterized by the orbito-frontal margin interrupted by an
   only fissure and adorned by an in relief and grained border. With the
   discovery of Raniliformis bellini n. Si). they increase to twelve the
   number of the species of Notopodinae known for the Venetian territory.
C1 De Angeli, Antonio; Piazzetta Nostro Tetto 9, Vicenza, Italy, Italy.
EM antonio.deangeli@alice.it
SC Zoology
SN 0392-9450
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene
DE Raniliformis bellini [Italy /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Brachyura
OR Raniliformis bellini (Brachyura): [Sp nov, Italy, Eocene, P. 104;
   Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14707049445
DT Article
TI Dynamenella miettoi n. sp., a new isopod (Crustacea, Flabellifera,
   Sphaeromatidae) from the Eocene of Veneto (Vicenza, NE Italy).
FT Dynamenella miettoi n. sp., nuovo isopode (Crustacea, Flabellifera,
   Sphaeromatidae) dell'Eocene del Veneto (Vicenza, Italia settentrionale).
AU De Angeli, Antonio (antonio.deangeli@alice.it) 
   Lovato, Alessandro
SO Societa Veneziana di Scienze Naturali Lavori
VL 36
PS 111-118
PD Gennaio 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Dynamenella miettoi n. sp. (Isopoda, Flabellifera, Sphaeromatidae) from
   the middle Eocene of Grola di Cornedo Vicentino (Vicenza, NE Italy) is
   described. The isopods, known to date from the Tertiary of Veneto, were
   limited to six species: Palaega acuticauda Secretan, 1975, Palaega
   catulloi (De Zigno, 1861), Cirolana fabianii De Angeli & Rossi, 2006,
   Heterosphaeroma veronensis Secretan, 1975, Sphaeroma gasparellai De
   Angeli & Lovato, 2009 and Sphaeroma sp. The new specie shows the
   pleotelson with three weak dorsal protuberances and a posterior median
   incision, and the body adorned by tubercles.
C1 De Angeli, Antonio; Piazzetta Nostro Tetto 9, Vicenza, Italy, Italy.
EM antonio.deangeli@alice.it

TI Myrmica radchenkoi, a New Species of Ant (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from
   Indian Himalaya.
AU Bharti, Himender (himenderbharti@gmail.com) 
   Sharma, Yash Paul
SO Sociobiology
VL 58
IS 2
PS 427-434
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Myrmica radchenkoi sp. nov. is reported from Indian Himalaya with
   discovery of workers and queen. This new species reinforces the
   placement of its close ally, earlier reported Myrmica rigatoi Radchenko
   and Elmes, 1998 in the inezae species group, where it has been
   provisionally placed so far. The queen in Myrmica radchenkoi sp. nov.
   which is described herewith also shows some close proximity with already
   described queen of Myrmica inezae.

DT Article
TI Divinotermes (Isoptera, Termitidae, Termitinae), a New Genus from South
   America.
AU Carrijo, Tiago Fernandes (tiagocarrijo@gmail.com) 
   Cancello, Eliana Marques
SO Sociobiology
VL 58
IS 3
PS 537-556
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The new termite genus Divinotermes is described, comprising D.
   allognathus comb.nov., previously included in Spinitermes, D.
   tuberculatus sp.nov. and D. digitatus sp.nov. The alate, soldier and
   worker castes of the new genus and the digestive tube and mandibles of
   workers are described, illustrated and compared with related genera. An
   identification key for soldiers and a distribution map for all species
   are provided. The new genus belongs to the South American Termes-group
   and has remarkable singular characters.

   Paulo, BR-04263000 BC, Brazil, Brazil.

TI Neivamyrmex albacorpus, a New Species of Ant (Hymenoptera: Formicidae:
   Ecitoninae) from Metztitlan, Hidalgo, Mexico.
AU Varela-Hernandez, Fernando
   Castano-Meneses, Gabriela (gabycast99@hotmail.com) 
SO Sociobiology
VL 58
IS 3
PS 579-584
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Workers of Neivamyrmex albacorpus, n. sp. (Hymenoptera: Formicidae:
   Ecitoninae) are described from ants collected at the Reserva de la
   Biosfera Barranca de Metztitlan, Hidalgo, Mexico. The distinctive
   characteristics of the species are the smooth yellowish-white body and
   the absence of eyes. The holotype worker is deposited in the CNIN at
   Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico.

TI Amblyopone boltoni, a New Ant Species (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from
   India.
AU Bharti, Himender (himenderbharti@gmail.com) 
   Wachkoo, Aijaz Ahmad
SO Sociobiology
VL 58
IS 3
PS 585-591
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Amblyopone boltoni sp. nov. is described from India. This is the fourth
   species of the genus known in India with A. bellii Forel, 1900, A.
   rothneyi Forel, 1900 and A. pertinax Baroni Urbani, 1978 reported
   earlier. This also confirms the first record of the subfamily
   Amblyoponinae from Northwest Himalaya. An identification key to the
   worker caste of Indian species has been provided.

TI Two new Inquiline Silverfish (Zygentoma: Ateluridae, Lepismatidae) From
   Malaysia.
AU Smith, Graeme B. (le_gbsmith@optusnet.com.au) 
   Veera Singham, G.
   Kuah, Meng-Kiat
   Lee, Chow-Yang
SO Sociobiology
VL 57
IS 1
PS 19-34
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Two new species of silverfish are described. Males and females of
   Xenolepisma penangi new species were collected from the nest of the ant
   Monomorium pharaonis (L.). It is the first record of this genus in South
   East Asia. Females only of Crypturelloides mindeni new genus and new
   species were collected from two separate colonies of the termite
   Globitermes sulphureus Haviland. Video footage of this species in the
   colony suggests the termite hosts totally ignore the activities of the
   silverfish.

PT J
AN ZOOR14705039745
DT Article
TI Paracurvitermes, a New Genus of Syntermitinae (Isoptera: Termitidae).
AU Constantino, Reginaldo (constant@unb.br) 
   Carvalho, Sergio H.C.
SO Sociobiology
VL 57
IS 2
PS 377-388
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Paracurvitermes, a new monotypic termite genus is described to
   accomodate Armitermes manni Snyder 1926. Soldiers are monomorphic and
   have a conical nasus with broad tip and elongate, curved mandibles. The
   imago-worker mandibles have very large apical teeth and reduced marginal
   teeth. The digestive tube of P manni is most similar to those of
   Macuxitermes and Noirotitermes. Soldiers, workers and imagoes are
   redescribed and figured. Curvitermes projectidens Mathews 1977 is a
   synonym of P manni. The diagnosis of Syntermitinae is reviewed.
C1 Constantino, Reginaldo; Univ Brasilia, Dept Zool, BR-70910900 Brasilia,
   DF, Brazil, Brazil.
EM constant@unb.br
RI Constantino, Reginaldo/J-2389-2015
OI Constantino, Reginaldo/0000-0003-2060-6723
SC Zoology
SN 0361-6525
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Synonymy; Land zones
DE Syntermitinae [Neotropical region /  / Distribution; systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Isoptera
OR Armitermes manni - Snyder 1926 (Isoptera): [Designated type species for
   new genus, Paracurvitermes, p. 380]. 
   Paracurvitermes (Isoptera): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Syntermitinae, Type
   species Armitermes manni Snyder 1926, p. 380]. 
   Paracurvitermes manni - (Snyder 1926) (Isoptera): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Armitermes (Armitermes), p. 382; Syn nov, Curvitermes projectidens
   Mathews 1977, p. 382]. 
   Syntermitinae - Engel & Krishna 2004 (Isoptera).

AB The paper presents the morphological, osteological, and zoogeographical
   characteristics of the slender racer Hierophis spinalis on the basis of
   collection data. A new genus, Orientocoluber, is proposed to be
   introduced for this snake. The morphological and zoogeographical
   distance of the new taxon from the genus Hierophis as well as from the
   other genera of the Coluber sensu lato group is discussed.

DT Article
TI Baldoplax bonizzatoi gen. nov., sp. nov. (Crustacea, Decapoda,
   Euryplacidae) from the Eocene of Ferrara di Monte Baldo (Verona, NE
   Italy).
FT Baldoplax bonizzatoi gen. nov., sp. nov., (Crustacea, Decapoda,
   Euryplacidae) dell'Eocene di Ferrara di Monte Baldo (Verona, Italia
   Settentrionale).
AU Beschin, Claudio (beschin.cl@libero.it) 
   De Angeli, Antonio
SO Studi e Ricerche Associazione Amici Museo Civico "G. Zannato" Montecchio
   Maggiore (VI)
VL 18
PS 5-10
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Baldoplax bonizzatoi gen. nov., sp. nov. (Crustacea, Decapoda,
   Brachyura, Euryplacidae) of the Early Eocene (Ypresian) of Ferrara di
   Monte Baldo (Verona, northern Italy) is described. The new taxon has
   affinity with the recent species of Eucrate and with Viaplax urpiniana
   Via Boada, 1959 from the Eocene of Spain. Baldoplax gen. nov. is
   characterized by large orbits, anterolateral margins with two small
   spines, very long and convergent posterolateral margins; slender
   careened posterior margin; not very defined regions, adorned by small
   tubercles and punctuations. It represents the most ancient recovery of
   Euryplacidae in Italy.
C1 Beschin, Claudio; Museo Civico &quot;G. Zannato&quot;, Piazza Marconi
   15, 36075 Montecchio Maggiore, (Vicenza), Italy, Italy.
EM beschin.cl@libero.it
SC Zoology
SN 1127-3100

   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene
DE Baldoplax [Eocene /  / New genus]. 
   Baldoplax bonizzatoi [Italy /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
   Euryplacidae [Italy /  / new record] [Eocene / Ypresian / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Brachyura

   Baldoplax bonizzatoi, p. 6, Eocene; Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14810068984
DT Article
TI The genus Ranina Lamarck, 1801 (Crustacea, Decapoda, Raninidae) in the
   Tertiary of Vicenza territory, with description of two new species.
FT Il genere Ranina Lamarck, 1801 (Crustacea, Decapoda, Raninidae) nel
   Terziario del Vicentino, con descrizione di due nuove specie.
AU de Angeli, Antonio (antonio.deangeli@alice.it) 
   Beschin, Claudio
SO Studi e Ricerche Associazione Amici Museo Civico "G. Zannato" Montecchio
   Maggiore (VI)
VL 18
PS 11-20
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The species of Ranina Lamarck, 1801 (Crustacea, Decapoda, Raninidae)
   reported in the literature from the Tertiary of the Vicenza, northern
   Italy) are considered. Ranina ornata sp. nov. from the Middle Eocene of
   Pradipaldo, R. pellattieroi sp. nov. from the Lower Miocene of Creazzo,
   and Ranina indeterminate species (1), Ranina indeterminate species (2)
   from the Lower Miocene of Creazzo (Vicenza) and the Upper Eocene of
   Alonte (Vicenza), are described. With the description of Ranina ornata
   sp. nov. and R. pellattieroi sp. nov., the number of known species of
   the family Raninidae Tertiary of Vicenza territory increases to 31.
   Ranina ornata sp. nov. probably represents the most ancient European
   recovery re-attributed to this genus.
C1 de Angeli, Antonio; Collaboratore del Museo Civico &quot;G.
   Zannato&quot;, Italy, Italy.
EM antonio.deangeli@alice.it

   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods;
   Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene; Palaeogene

TI [New species of gastropods (Mollusca, Gastropoda) from the Eocene of
   Italy. Part 1: Neritimorpha.]
FT Nouvelles especes de gasteropodes (Mollusca, Gastropoda) de l'Eocene
   d'Italie. partie 1: Neritimorpha.
AU Pacaud, Jean-Michel (pacaud@mnhn.fr) 
   Quaggiotto, Ermanno
SO Studi e Ricerche Associazione Amici Museo Civico "G. Zannato" Montecchio
   Maggiore (VI)
VL 18
PS 21-29
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new species of the gastropod taxa of the family Neritidae and
   Neritopsidae in the Ypresian and Lutetian (Eocene) of Italy are
   described: Pileolus albertii sp. nov., Velatella eocaenica sp. nov.,
   Cuisenerita dysporista sp. nov. and Neritopsis carmenae sp. nov. This is
   the first record of Pileolus and Velatella in Cenozoic. Neritopsis
   (s.str.) pulcella nov. sp. is proposed as replacement name for
   Neritopsis (s.str) parisiensis sensu Merle, 1984 non Deshayes, 1864.

PT J
AN ZOOR15407044101
DT Article
TI Daubaylia n. sp. (Nematoda, Daubayliidae), a parasite of the snail Helix
   aspersa (Mueller) (Mollusca, Pulmonata, Helicidae) from Argentina.
AU Camino, Nora B. (nemainst@cpave.edu.ar) 
   Gonzalez, Sandra E.
SO Studi Trentini di Scienze Naturali
VL 88
PS 29-32
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Daubaylia n. sp. (Nematoda, Daubayliidae), a parasite of the snail Helix
   aspersa (Muller) (Mollusca, Pulmonata, Helicidae) from Argentina -
   Daubaylia bonaerensis n. sp. (Nematoda, Daubayliidae), a parasite of the
   snail Helix aspersa (Muller) (Mollusca, Pulmonata, Helicidae) from
   Argentina, is described and illustrated. This new species is
   characterized in male spicules long, parallel inside the body, but when
   it projected outward cross. Strong gubernaculum triangular sharp-size.
   Genital papillae almost not visible at optical microscope, six pairs of
   preanal papillae, one single papilla on the side just above the anus,
   one pair of adanal papillae, and one pair of postanal papillae. Female
   with vulva protruding. Vagina barrel shaped, muscular and strong. Uterus
   in female mature with nine eggs unsegmented. Tail appendage long,
   conical, straight and strong.
C1 Camino, Nora B.; Centro de Estudios Parasitologicos y de Vectores,
   CEPAVE (CCT La Plata - CONICET-UNLP-CIC), Calle 2 no 584, 1900 La Plata,
   Argentina, Argentina.
EM nemainst@cpave.edu.ar
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 2035-7699
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Daubaylia bonaerensis [Molluscan hosts / Helix aspersa / New parasite
   species] [Argentina /  / New species from molluscan host]. 
   Helix aspersa [Nematode parasites / Daubaylia bonaerensis / New parasite
   species] [Argentina /  / New nematode parasite species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Pulmonata, Stylommatophora, Helicoidea,
   Nematoda
OR Helix aspersa (Helicoidea): [Host]. 
   Daubaylia bonaerensis (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Argentina, Parasite of Helix
   aspersa (Mollusca), p. 30; Parasite].

TI Limonia zwicki spec. nov., a new species of Limoniidae (Diptera) from
   East Kazakhstan.
AU Devyatkov, Vladimir I. (devyatkovvi@inbox.ru) 
SO Studia Dipterologica
VL 18
IS 1-2
PS 21-25
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of short-palped crane flies, Limonia zwicki spec. nov., is
   described from East Kazakhstan and compared with related Palaearctic
   species of the genus. The males of the new species are distinguished
   from all known males of Palaearctic Limonia species by having a pointed
   median projection at the posterior margin of sternite 8.

TI A new species of Hemerodromia MEIGEN (Diptera: Empididae:
   Hemerodromiinae) from Late Eocene Rovno Amber.
AU Plant, Adrian R. (Adrian.Plant@museumwales.ac.uk) 
   Shamshev, Igor
   Perkovsky, Evgeny
SO Studia Dipterologica
VL 18
IS 1-2
PS 79-84
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Hemerodromia grootaerti PLANT & SHAMSHEV spec. nov. (Empididae:
   Hemerodromiinae) is described from Late Eocene Rovno amber. It is
   unusual in retaining the plesiomorphic condition of the wing in which
   the subcostal vein is free basally and the humeral crossvein is present.
   Historical dispersal patterns of the genus Hemerodromia MEIGEN, 1822
   from northern centres of radiation are discussed.
C1 Plant, Adrian R.; Natl Museum Wales, Dept Biodivers & Systemat Biol,
   Cathays Pk, Cardiff, S Glam, CF10 3NP, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.

   species.

VL 18

AB A total of 38 species belonging to six genera of Sepsidae is reported
   from Thailand. Four species (Dicranosepsis biformis IWASA spec. nov., D.
   notata IWASA spec. nov., D. robusta IWASA spec. nov., D. thailandia

DT Article
TI Revision of European species of the Empis (s. str.) pennipes group of
   species (Diptera: Empididae), with descriptions of five new species from
   the Mediterranean and the Caucasus.
AU Chvala, Milan (mchvala@iol.cz) 
SO Studia Dipterologica
VL 18
IS 1-2
PS 173-193
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Empis pennipes group of species is clearly defined, and is
   represented by large sized species with simple large male genitalia with
   a long free aedeagus, and long slender unmodified legs. Western
   Palaearctic species of this group of the subgenus Empis s. str.
   (Diptera: Empididae), with Empis pennipes LINNAEUS, 1758 as type of the
   genus, are revised. Altogether 13 species are recognized, of which five
   are described as new for science: one (Empis provencalis spec. nov.)
   from western Switzerland and the southeast of France, and four species
   from the Caucasus: Empis caucasidecora spec. nov., Empis brendae spec.
   nov., Empis aceponti spec. nov., and Empis planti spec. nov. A key to
   the species of this group is given.
C1 Chvala, Milan; Charles Univ, Dept Zool, Vinicna 7, Praha, CR-12844,
   Czech Republic, Czech Republic.

   [Georgia-Asia /  / New species].

TI Records of Ephydridae (Diptera) from Jordan, with the description of
   five new species.
FT Funde von Ephydridae (Diptera) aus Jordanien, mit der Beschreibung von
   funf neuen Arten.

SO Studia Dipterologica
VL 18
IS 1-2
PS 197-224
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Records of 50 species of Ephydridae are reported from Jordan.
   Fifty-three ephydrid species are now known from Jordan in total. Three
   additional taxa cannot be identified to genus and seven additional taxa
   cannot be identified to species. Athyroglossa (Athyroglossa)flavicoxa
   spec. nov., Eremotrichoma mathisi spec. nov., Parydra danensis spec.
   nov., Scatella (Neoscatella) karakensis spec. nov. and Typopsilopa
   jordaniensis spec. nov. are described. The postabdomina of Psilopa
   aequalipes (BECKER, 1907), Psilopa nigricornis HENDEL, 1931 and
   Typopsilopa kerteszi PAP?, 1975 are illustrated in addition to those of
   the new species. A lectotype is designated for Psilopa aequalipes
   (BECKER, 1907).

AN ZOOR14805033667
DT Article
TI Overview and description of fossil non-biting midges in Baltic amber
   (Diptera: Chironomidae).
AU Seredszus, Fabian (fabian.seredszus@uni-koeln.de) 
   Wichard, Wilfried
SO Studia Dipterologica
VL 17
IS 1-2
PS 121-129
PD 2010(2011)
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We describe two new fossil species of the subfamily Tanypodinae:
   Procladius eocenicus spec. nov. and Coelotanypus antiquus spec. nov..
   and give a short overviews of the 30 fossil chironomid species found in
   Baltic amber. These belong to 26 genera and to the following 6
   subfamilies: Prodiamesinae (1 species). Podonominae (3). Tanypodinae
   (4), Buchonomyiinae (1), Orthocladiinae (17). and Chironominae (4). The
   chironomid fauna of Baltic amber consists of only two extinct but 24
   extant genera, which indicates a close relationship to present-day
   chironomids. Details of the diagnostic characters and determination of
   chironomids from Baltic amber are briefly discussed.
C1 Seredszus, Fabian; Institut fuer Biologie, Universitaet zu Koeln,
   Gronewaldstrasse 2, 50931 Koeln, Germany, Germany.
EM fabian.seredszus@uni-koeln.de
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0945-3954
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Documentation; Publications;
   Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Geological time
   periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Chironomidae [Checklists /  / overview; fossil taxa in amber] [Ecology /
    / ] [Europe / Baltic region / ]. 
   Coelotanypus antiquus; Procladius eocenicus [Eocene /  / New species;
   Described from amber]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies

DT Article
TI Black fungus gnats (Diptera: Sciaridae) from tap roots of Rumex
   obtusifolius Linnaeus in south-west Thuringia (Germany), with comments
   on the variability of Bradysia scabricornis Tuomikoski.
FT Trauermuecken (Diptera: Sciaridae) aus Pfahlwurzeln von Rumex
   obtusifolius Linnaeus in Suedwest-Thueringen (Deutschland), mit
   Bemerkungen zur Variabilitaet von Bradysia scabricornis Tuomikoski.
AU Menzel, Frank (frank.menzel@senckenberg.de) 
   Mueller, Werner A.H.
SO Studia Dipterologica
VL 17
IS 1-2
PS 161-171
PD 2010(2011)
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Tap roots without fresh growth were dug up in 2007 and 2008 from six
   stands of Rumex obtusifolius L. located in different localities in the
   Federal State of Thuringia. Black fungus gnats (Sciaridae) belonging to
   the species Bradysia scabricornis TUOMIKOSKI, 1960, Bradysia vagans
   (WINNERTZ, 1868), Corynoptera subparvula TUOMIKOSKI, 1960, Epidapus
   absconditus (VIMMER, 1926), Lycoriella castanescens (LENGERSDORF, 1940)
   and Lycoriella ingenua (DUFOUR, 1839) emerged from the tap roots without
   new growth. Under field conditions, the imagines of Bradysia
   scabricornis, Epidapus absconditus and Lycoriella castanescens emerged
   from the end of May to the end of June. The influence of temperature on
   the development and emergence of the sciarids is discussed using the
   example of the observed species. Furthermore, on the basis of rearing
   results, Bradysia subscabricornis MOHRIG&MENZEL, 1990 syn. nov. is shown
   to be a junior synonym of Bradysia scabricornis TUOMIKOSKI, 1960.
C1 Menzel, Frank; Senckenberg Deutsches Entomologisches Institut
   Eberswalder Strasse 90, 15374 Muencheberg, Germany, Germany.
EM frank.menzel@senckenberg.de

   Sciaridae [Germany / Thuringia, southwest / Biology; faunal list;
   systematics].

OR Sciaridae (Nematocera).

PT J
AN ZOOR14802015180
DT Article
TI Tethyan radiolarians at the Cenomanian-Turonian Anoxic Event from the
   Apennines (Umbria-Marche) and the Outer Carpathians: palaeoecological
   and palaeoenvironmental implications.
AU Bak, Marta (marta.bak@uj.edu.pl) 
SO Studia Geologica Polonica
VL 134
PS 1-279
PD 2011
PY 2011
NT Methods and Applications in Micropaleontology Part II. Edited by:
   Tyszka, J. Separate unpaginated tables.
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The radiolarian fauna from deep-water settings in the Umbria- Marche and
   the Outer Carpathian basins of the Western Tethys is used for
   biostratigraphic purpose and interpretation of environmental changes
   during the late Cenomanian through the Early Turonian time interval. The
   frequency of 184 recognized species, thirteen of them newly described,
   has been processed and analyzed. Three radiolarian biozones and one
   subzone are distinguished based on radiolarian datum events, correlated
   with the chronostratigraphic scale through the S'3C curve. The whole
   radiolarian set has been subdivided into six super groups, including 25
   groups related to specific water masses. The assembled species
   represented various feeding preferences and ecological strategies. An
   increase of radiolarian total number in the sediments related to the
   Bonarelli Level (BL) displays a positive correlation with an increase of
   phosphorus (P) content, and with a significant decrease in radiolarian
   diversity. Most of radiolarian species avoided levels with high P
   content, in contrast, some species as H. barbui and C. conara increased
   significantly in number of specimens. Diversified radiolarian
   assemblages appeared at levels, directly preceded by a notable P
   increase, marking a period when the water system was saturated in
   relation to nitrogen. The radiolarian abundance in the sediments was
   strongly related to their preservation during sinking in the water
   column and at the water/sediment interface, increasing significantly at
   levels, marked by high pellet production. Thus, pelletization played an
   important role in the transport of radiolarian skeletons and their
   further preservation, irrespective to conditions of radiolarians growth.
   Radiolarians experienced and responded to environmental changes during
   the 1.8 Ma around the Bonarelli Interval (BI). The Cenomanian[long
   dash]Turonian press extinction event [long dash] a period of
   unquestionable eutrophication represented by the BI, did not result in
   great radiolarian extinction and turnovers. The radiolarian radiation
   preceded the BI by over 330 ka. The extinction, directly connected with
   the OAE2 started ca. 240 ka before the end of the organic-rich
   sedimentation, coinciding with the onset of enhanced diatom frustules
   deposition, recorded in the siliceous part of the BI. Since this period,
   a step-wise radiolarian extinction continued through the Early Turonian.
   Many of the radiolarian species previously considered as terminating
   during the BI, in fact outlived up to "post-Bonarelli" times, having
   their last occurrence after the BI or even in the Early Turonian. In the
   case of the radiolarian fauna, the Bonarelli period caused the
   disappearance of many Lazarus taxa, which returned in almost their
   initial state during 940 ka after the BI. The current radiolarian study
   sheds light on the biological effects of anoxic events, indicating the
   role of the mesopelagic zone and oceanic circulation in nutrient
   exchange, which modulates and controls the OAE2. The mesopelagic zone
   played an important role in P sequestration and was responsible for the
   release of the most of P, leading to enhanced eutrophication of water
   column.
C1 Bak, Marta; Institute of Geological Sciences, Jagiellonian University,
   Oleandry 2a, 30-063, Krakow, Poland, Poland.
EM marta.bak@uj.edu.pl
RI Bak, Marta/A-5748-2017
OI Bak, Marta/0000-0001-9329-3540
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0081-6426
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Abiotic factors; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods;
   Mesozoic
DE Acaeniotyle bispina; Becus doryphoros; Cretathamnus pharus; Crolanium
   abstemius; Crolanium enodis; Dactyliosphaera andromeda; Diacanthocapsa
   architenens; Diacanthocapsa dextra; Diacanthocapsa perfluxa;
   Diacanthocapsa ratiforma; Obeloscoites bifrons; Paronaella permira;
   Staurosphaeretta octaspina [Italy /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Cretathamnus [Cretaceous /  / New genus].

DT Article
TI Notes on Afrotropical species of the genus Dyschiriodes (Coleoptera:
   Carabidae: Scaritinae) with descriptions of three new taxa.
AU Bulirsch, Petr (p.bulirsch@seznam.cz) 
SO Studies and Reports of District Museum Prague-East Taxonomical Series
VL 7
IS 1-2
PS 1-12
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species and one new subspecies of the genus Dyschiriodes
   Jeannel, 1941, are described, illustrated and compared to the related
   taxa: D. (Eudyschirius) natalensis hogani ssp. nov. and D.
   (Eudyschirius) snizeki sp. nos, from Zambia and D. smetanai sp. nov.
   from Burkina Faso. The types of D. arcanus (Bruneau de Mire, 1952), D.
   allaeri (Kull, 1954) and D. havelkai (Kult, 1954) are redescribed, new
   findings are cited and synonymy of both latter species with D. arcanus
   is confirmed or established. The type and additional material of D.
   kalanganus (Burgeon, 1935) and its junior synonym, D. bredoi (Kull,
   1954), are studied, its synonymy is confirmed and new findings are
   quoted; D. moelleri (Kult, 1954) is redescribed and its synonymy with D.
   katanganus is established.
C1 Bulirsch, Petr; Milanska 461, CZ-109 00 Praha 111, Czech Republic, Czech
   Republic.
EM p.bulirsch@seznam.cz

TI A revision of the genus Antireicheia Basilewsky from Tanzania with
   descriptions of two new species (Coleoptera: Carabidae: Scaritinae).
AU Bulirsch, Petr (p.bulirsch@seznam.cz) 
   Magrini, Paolo
SO Studies and Reports of District Museum Prague-East Taxonomical Series
VL 7
IS 1-2
PS 13-24
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Holotypes and additional material of four to date known species of the
   endogean carabid genus Antireicheia Basilewsky, 1951, from Tanzania are
   studied, redescribed and new records are given. Two Tanzanian species
   are described as new: A. alesi sp. nov. from Uluguru Mts. and A.
   nguruensis sp. nov. from Nguru Mts., and all species including their
   aedeagi and female styli are illustrated. A key to Tanzanian
   Antireicheia species is provided.
C1 Bulirsch, Petr; Milanska 461, CZ-109 00 Praha 111, Czech Republic, Czech
   Republic.
EM p.bulirsch@seznam.cz

   zones; Afrotropical region; Africa

   P. 14].

PT J
AN ZOOR14802016351
DT Article
TI Megarthrus of Taiwan, with notes on phylogenetic relationships within
   the genus (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Proteininae).
AU Cuccodoro, Giulio (giulio.cuccodoro@ville-ge.ch) 
SO Studies and Reports of District Museum Prague-East Taxonomical Series
VL 7
IS 1-2
PS 25-92
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Megarthrus is reported here for the first time from Taiwan, where it
   appears to be represented by species, fourteen of which being new (M.
   con sp. nov., M. testivus sp. nov., M globulus sp. nov., M. lisae sp.
   nov., M. magnificus sp. nov., M. metanas sp. nov., M mirabilis sp. nov.,
   M. octopus sp. nov., M. phoenix sp. M. ping sp. nov., M splendidus sp.
   nov., M. tac sp. nov., M. taiwanus sp. nov., and M tic sp. nov.). The
   species, M. flavolimbatus Cameron, is reported for the first time out of
   North India and becomes the first transoriental species of Megarthrus.
   These species are keyed, their genital segments and main diagnostic
   characters figured, and their apparent phylogenetic relationships are
   discussed. They appear to belong to ten distinct Megarthrus
   species-complex, of which seven species are Himalayan and/or
   East-Palaearctic elements, two seem to Taiwan (i.e. festivus-complex and
   M. phoenix), while the last is dominant in the Palaearctic, Nearctic
   Afrotropical realms and Taiwan shares only one species with the Eurasian
   continent.
C1 Cuccodoro, Giulio; Museum d'histoire naturelle, C.P. 6434, CH-1211
   Geneve 6, Switzerland, Switzerland.
EM giulio.cuccodoro@ville-ge.ch
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Evolution;
   Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Megarthrus [Phylogeny /  / new record; systematics] [Zoogeography /  / ]
   [Taiwan /  / Key to species] [ /  / ]. 
   Megarthrus con; Megarthrus festivus; Megarthrus globulus; Megarthrus
   lisae; Megarthrus magnificus; Megarthrus metanas; Megarthrus mirabilis;
   Megarthrus octopus; Megarthrus phoenix; Megarthrus ping; Megarthrus
   splendidus; Megarthrus tac; Megarthrus taiwanus; Megarthrus tic [Taiwan
   /  / New species]. 
   Megarthrus flavolimbatus [Taiwan /  / Distribution; new record]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Staphylinidae
OR Megarthrus - Curtis 1829 (Staphylinidae): [Key to species, Taiwan, P.
   26; New record]. 
   Megarthrus con (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 27]. 
   Megarthrus festivus (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 34]. 
   Megarthrus flavolimbatus (Staphylinidae): [New record]. 
   Megarthrus globulus (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 39]. 
   Megarthrus lisae (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 44]. 
   Megarthrus magnificus (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 50]. 
   Megarthrus metanas (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 50]. 
   Megarthrus mirabilis (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 55]. 
   Megarthrus octopus (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 59].

DT Article
TI A review of genus Protapatophysis Semenov-Tian-Shanskij et
   Stschegoleva-Barovskaia, 1936 stat. nov. (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae:
   Apatophyseinae).
AU Danilevsky, Mikhail L. (danilevskyml@rambler.ru) 
SO Studies and Reports of District Museum Prague-East Taxonomical Series
VL 7
IS 1-2
PS 93-104
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Protapatophysis Semenov-Tian-Shanskij et Stschegoleva-Barovskaia, 1936
   stat. nov. is raised to the genus level from a subgenus of Apatophysis
   Chevrolat, 1860 based on big parallel-sided body in males, strongly
   developed tarsi pads, closed anterior coxal cavities and approached hind
   coxae in females; Protapatophysis consists of 4 species distributed in
   high mountains from north-east Afghanistan to Kashmir and Western
   Himalayas: P. kashmiriana (Semenov, 1901), comb. nov., P. montana
   (Gahan, 1906), comb. nov., P. vartianae (Heyrovsky, 1971), comb. nov.
   and P. kahakovi sp. nov. described from Konar province of Afghanistan. A
   lectotype is designated for Apatophysis kashmiriana Semenov, 1901. The
   area of P. vartianae is widely distributed south- and eastwards to India
   along south Himalayan slopes.
C1 Danilevsky, Mikhail L.; A. N. Severtzov Institute of Ecology and
   Evolution, Russian Academy of Sciences, Leninsky prospect 33, Moscow,
   119071, Russia, Russia.
EM danilevskyml@rambler.ru
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Status; Key; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Protapatophysis kabakovi [Afghanistan /  / New species]. 
   Protapatophysis vartianae [Himachal Pradesh / Chamba / Distribution]
   [Pakistan /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Cerambycidae
OR Apatophysis (Protapatophysis) - Semenov-Tian-Shanskij &
   Stschegoleva-Barovskaia 1935 (Cerambycidae): [Raised to,
   Protapatophysis, p. 94]. 
   Apatophysis (Protapatophysis) vartianae - Heyrovsky 1971 (Cerambycidae):
   [Referred to, Protapatophysis, p. 97]. 
   Apatophysis kashmiriana - Semenov 1901 (Cerambycidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 95; Referred to, Protapatophysis, p. 95]. 
   Centrodera (Apatophysis) montana - Gahan 1906 (Cerambycidae): [Referred
   to, Protapatophysis, p. 102]. 
   Protapatophysis - Semenov-Tian-Shanskij & Stschegoleva-Barovskaia 1935
   (Cerambycidae): [Raised from, Apatophysis (Protapatophysis), p. 94; Key
   to species, Males, p. 103]. 
   Protapatophysis kabakovi (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Afghanistan, P. 101]. 
   Protapatophysis kashmiriana - (Semenov 1901) (Cerambycidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Apatophysis, p. 95]. 
   Protapatophysis montana - (Gahan 1906) (Cerambycidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Centrodera (Apatophysis), p. 102]. 
   Protapatophysis vartianae - (Heyrovsky 1971) (Cerambycidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Apatophysis (Protapatophysis), p. 97].

TI A description of two new species of Anillina from North Carolina with
   notes about the geographical distribution of the genus Anillinus Casey,
   1918 (Coleoptera: Carabidae: Bembidiini).

AB Two new species of anilline ground beetles are described from the
   Appalachian Mountains of eastern United States: Anillinus campbelli sp.
   nov. from Van Hook Glade, 4 mi. W Highlands (NC) and Anillinus pecki sp.
   nov. from three sites along the Blue Ridge Pkwy (Avery and Wilkes
   Counties, NC). New chorological data about Inillinus lowae Sokolov et
   Carlton, 2004, A. steevesi Barr, 1995, A. langdoni Sokolov et Carlton,
   2004 and A. barri Sokolov et Carlton, 2004 are given.

AB Globicornis (s. str.) luckowi sp. nov. from Switzerland is described,
   illustrated and compared with a related species Globicornis (s. str.)
   nigripes (Fabricius, 1792). A topical checklist of the dermestid species
   from Switzerland is provided.

   Germany.

TI Contribution to knowledge of the genus Cryptorhopalum Guerin-Meneville,

   Hava, Jiri

VL 7
IS 1-2
PS 145-149
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Cryptorhopalum brulei sp. nov. is described, illustrated and compared
   with a related species Cryptorhopalum trogodermoides Reitter, 1881. Two
   species, Cryptorhopalum quadripunctatum Guerin-Meneville, 1838 and
   Cryptorhopalum orbiculosum Reitter, 1881, are recorded for the first
   time from French Guiana.

PT J
AN ZOOR14802016372
DT Article
TI Revision of Afrotropical species of the Philonthus peliomerus species
   group (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Philonthina).
AU Hromadka, Lubomir (hromadkal@seznam.cz) 
SO Studies and Reports of District Museum Prague-East Taxonomical Series
VL 7
IS 1-2
PS 151-188
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Philonthus peliomerus species group of the genus Philonthus
   Stephens, 1829, is proposed, containing 24 species. Seven species are
   described as new taxa: Philonthus accipiter sp. nov. (Kenya), Philonthus
   alcelaphus sp. nov. (Ethiopia), P. crocidura sp. nov. (Zaire), P.
   infrdelis sp. nov. (Zambia), P. labeo sp. nov. (Republic of South
   Africa), P. vidua sp. nov. (Ethiopia), P. xenopus sp. nov. (Burundi).
   The remaining 17 species are redescribed as follows: P. angolensis
   Cameron, 1959, P. bottegoi Eppelsheim, 1895, P. cribricephalicus
   Tottenham, 1949, P. cylindricollis Cameron, 1934, P. diatrechoides
   Tottenham, 1962, P. flavoterminatus Wollaston, 1877, P. inimicus
   Tottenham, 1962, P. inipendezius Tottenham, 1962, P. leonensis Cameron,
   1934, P. motoensis Cameron, 1929, P. nimeikopus Tottenham, 1962, P.
   paederomimus Eppelsheim, 1895, P. peliomeroides Cameron, 1934, P.
   peliomerus Kraatz, 1859, P. peliomixtus Tottenham, 1962, P. rudebecki
   Scheerpeltz, 1974, P. uelensis Bernhauer, 1928. All the species of the
   P. peliomerus species group are keyed and their aedeagi and relevant
   morphological characters are figured.
C1 Hromadka, Lubomir; Anny Letenske 7, CZ-120 00 Praha 2, Czech Republic,
   Czech Republic.
EM hromadkal@seznam.cz
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Key; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa

   Philonthus labeo [South Africa /  / New species]. 
   Philonthus peliomerus species group [Afrotropical region /  /
   Systematics]. 
   Philonthus xenopus [Burundi /  / New species].

   Staphylinidae

   (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Philonthina).

VL 7

PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Ten new species of the genus Philonthus Stephens, 1829 (Coleoptera:
   Staphylinidae) are described as follows: Philonthus alessmetanai sp.
   nov. (Sierra Leone), Philonthus alesi sp. nov. (Ethiopia), Philonthus
   emberiza sp. nov. (Democratic Republic of the Congo), Philonthus
   haliaeetus sp. nov. (Rwanda, Tanzania), Philonthus haliophis sp. nov.
   (Kenya), Philonthus indicator sp. nov. (Ethiopia), Philonthus lutjanus
   sp. nov. (Kenya), Philonthus melaenornis sp. nov. (Zimbabwe), Philonthus
   polemaetus sp. nov. (Tanzania), Philonthus procavia sp. nov. (Burundi).
   All the species are described, illustrated and compared with related
   species.

TI New species of the family Rhynchitidae (Coleoptera) from Asia and
   Africa.
AU Legalov, Andrei (legalov@ngs.ru) 
SO Studies and Reports of District Museum Prague-East Taxonomical Series
VL 7
IS 1-2
PS 291-299
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Five new species of the family Rhynchitidae from Africa and Asia are
   described and illustrated. Pseudomesauletes (Metallauletes) marshalli
   sp. nov. from Kenya looks like P. (M.) kuntzeni (Voss, 1922), Deporaus
   (Deporaus) hengjanensis sp. nov. from Shanxi is similar to D. (D.)
   betulae (Linnaeus, 1758), Involvulus harunamt, sp. nov. from Nepal looks
   like I. gemmus (Semenov-Tian-Shanskij et Ter-Minassian, 1937),
   Cm.torhynchites (Cartorhynchites) baliensis sp. nov. from Indonesia is
   lake to C. (C.) nantouensus Legalov, 2007 and Auletomotphus
   (Auletomorphus) habashanensis sp. nov. from China is similar to A. (A.)
   tonkinensis (Voss, 1924).

PT J
AN ZOOR14802016392
DT Article
TI On the Scaphisomatini (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Scaphidiinae) of the
   Philippines.
AU Loebl, Ivan
SO Studies and Reports of District Museum Prague-East Taxonomical Series
VL 7
IS 1-2
PS 301-313
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Philippine members of three informal Scaphisomatini groups are reviewed.
   The Birocera group is by two genera, Birocera and Bironium, comprising
   six species. Birocera basicollis is described as new, is redescribed and
   reported for the first time from the Philippines. Bironium is
   represented by four of them, B. pustulatum, is described as new. Keys to
   the Philippine species of Birocera and Bironium The Amalaocera group is
   represented by a single species, Pseudobironium banonense (Pic, 1931),
   and m obscuricolle (Pic, 1947) is placed in its synonymy. The
   Toxidium-group is represented by members and Scaphoxium. Scaphoxium
   alesi is described as new, and S. taylori is reported for the first time
   Philippines.
C1 Loebl, Ivan; Museum d'histoire naturelle, Case postale 6343, CH-1211
   Geneva 6, Switzerland, Switzerland.
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Key; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Birocera basicollis; Bironium pustulatum; Scaphoxium alesi [Philippines
   /  / New species]. 
   Bironium; Scaphicoma; Scaphoxium [Philippines /  / Key to species]. 
   Scaphisomatini [Philippines /  / Distribution; new record; systematics].
   
   Scaphoxium taylori [Philippines /  / Distribution; new record]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Staphylinidae
OR Birocera - Lobl 1970 (Staphylinidae): [Key to species, P. 302]. 
   Birocera basicollis (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Philippines, P. 302]. 
   Birocera punctatissima - (Reitter 1880) (Staphylinidae): [Redescription,
   P. 305]. 
   Bironium - Csiki 1909 (Staphylinidae): [Key to species, Philippines, P.
   306]. 
   Bironium pustulatum (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Philippines, P. 306]. 
   Pseudobironium banonense - (Pic 1931) (Staphylinidae): [Syn nov,
   Pseudobironium obscuricolle (Pic 1947), p. 308]. 
   Scaphicoma - Motschulsky 1863 (Staphylinidae): [Key to species,
   Philippines, P. 309].

DT Article
TI New genera of Alleculinae (Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae) from Oriental
   region Part III. Microsthes gen. nov.
AU Novak, Vladimir (alleculinnae.vn@centrum.cz) 
SO Studies and Reports of District Museum Prague-East Taxonomical Series
VL 7
IS 1-2
PS 319-334
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Genus Microsthes gen. nov. with the species Microsthes barborae sp. nov.
   as a type species from Malaysia. Microsthes bruggei sp. nov. and
   Microsthes molucensis sp. nov. from Indonesia, Microsthes cameronensis
   sp. nov., Microsthes rolciki sp. nov. and Microsthes zizui sp. nov. from
   Malaysia are described, illustrated and keyed. Species belonged to the
   new genus Microsthes gen. nov. differs from the species belonged to the
   similar genus Borboresthes Fairmaire, 1897 mainly by small body,
   penultimate tarsomere indistinctly broadened, antennomeres 3-10 broader,
   distinctly broadest at apex, and from similar genus Borbochara Novak,
   2009 mainly by pronotum without backwards thornly extended sharp-angled
   posterior angles and by space between eyes distinctly broader than
   length of antennomere 2.
C1 Novak, Vladimir; Nepasicke namesti 796, CZ-190 14 Prague 9, Klanovice,
   Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM alleculinnae.vn@centrum.cz
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Microsthes barborae; Microsthes cameronensis; Microsthes rolciki;
   Microsthes zizui [Malaysia /  / New species]. 
   Microsthes bruggei; Microsthes molucensis [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Tenebrionoidea,
   Tenebrionidae
OR Microsthes (Tenebrionidae): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Alleculinae, Type
   species Microsthes barborae, p. 320; Key to species, P. 321]. 
   Microsthes barborae (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Malaysia, P. 322]. 
   Microsthes bruggei (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 324].

   Microsthes zizui (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Malaysia, P. 332].

DT Article
TI New Allecula species (Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae: Alleculinae) from
   Turkey.
AU Novak, Vladimir (alleculinnae.vn@centrum.cz) 
   Jansson, Nicklas
   Avci, Mustafa
   Sarikaya, Oguzhan
   Coskun, Mustafa
   Atay, Erol
   Gurkan, Tolga
SO Studies and Reports of District Museum Prague-East Taxonomical Series
VL 7
IS 1-2
PS 335-346
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Old oaks (Quercus spp) are rare all over Europe and Turkey and members
   of the fauna living in these habitats are threatened. Nine stands with
   old hollow oaks, spread on five areas, were studied in Turkey over
   2005-2009. In total 90 hollow oaks were studied. The studied oak species
   are Quercus cerris, Q. injectoria, Q. trojana, Q. libanii, Q. puhescens,
   Q. ithahurensis and Q. vulcanica. The same methods have been used for
   sampling the beetles: window traps on the tree trunk and pit fall traps
   in the wood mould inside the trunk cavities. The traps have been in
   field from middle of April to the end of September during one season per
   area from 2005 to 2009. The studied areas are all situated 50-150 km
   from the southern Mediterranean coast at altitudes between 1100-1500 m
   except one at a lower altitude. In this study two new Allecula species
   were found: Allecula janssoni Novak sp. nov. and Allecula tun-Ica Novak
   sp. nov. The species are presently described, illustrated and keyed with
   all the western Palaearctic species. Both species are probably
   saproxylic as the other species in the genus and for larval development,
   they use rotten wood in the trunk cavities.
C1 Novak, Vladimir; Nepasicke namesti 796, CZ-190 14 Prague 9, Klanovice,
   Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM alleculinnae.vn@centrum.cz
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Biometrics; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Allecula [Europe /  / Key to species]. 
   Allecula janssoni; Allecula turcica [Turkey /  / New species]. 
   Allecula rhenana [Size / Measurements / Recorded] [Turkey /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Tenebrionoidea,
   Tenebrionidae
OR Allecula - Fabricius 1801 (Tenebrionidae): [Key to species, Europe,
   Males, p. 338]. 
   Allecula janssoni - Novak 2011 (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Turkey, P.
   338]. 
   Allecula rhenana (Tenebrionidae). 
   Allecula turcica - Novak 2011 (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Turkey, P. 342].
   
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14802016398
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14802016400
DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Paracistela Borchmann, 1941 (Coleoptera:
   Tenebrionidae: Alleculinae).
AU Novak, Vladimir (alleculinnae.vn@centrum.cz) 
SO Studies and Reports of District Museum Prague-East Taxonomical Series
VL 7
IS 1-2
PS 347-381
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Paper discusses the revision of the genus Paracistela Borchmann, 1941.
   Three species are transformed from the genus Isomira Mulsant, 1856 -
   Paracistela brunneosuturalis (Pic, 1917) comb. nov. from India (Khasia
   Hills). Paracistela laosensis (Pic, 1934) comb. nov. from Laos and
   Paracistela sinensis (Pic, 1934) comb. nov. from China; two species are
   transformed from the genus Pseudocistela Crotch, 1 873 - Paracistela
   luteopubens (Pic, 1913) comb. nov. from Tonkin and Paracistela
   rufithorax (Pic, 1913) comb. nov. from Oriental region. Paracistela
   variabilis Borchmann, 1941 is new synonym of Paracistela luteopubens.
   Neotype of Paracistela brunneosuturalis (Pic, 1917) comb. nov. is
   designated here; as well as Paracistela laosensis (Pic, 1934) comb.
   nov., Paracistela sinensis (Pic, 1934) comb. nov. and Paracistela
   rufithorax (Pic, 1913) comb. nov. are redescripted here. Ten new species
   Paracistela alesi sp. nov., Paracistela havai sp. nov., Paracistela
   houaphanica sp. nov. and Paracistela bull sp. nov. from Laos,
   Paracistela bengali sp. nov. from India (Darjeeling), Paracistela
   namuangica sp. nov., Paracistela soppongica sp. nov. and Paracistela
   zahradniki sp. nov. from Thailand, Paracistela smetanai sp. nov. from
   China (Jiangxi) and Paracistela weigeli sp. nov. from China (Yunnan) are
   presently described, illustrated and keyed with other species of this
   genus. New distributional data (Laos and North Vietnam) are added for
   Paracistela luteopubens (Pic, 1913) comb. nov. and Paracistela laosensis
   (Pic, 1934) is new for territory of Thailand
C1 Novak, Vladimir; Nepasicke namesti 796, CZ-190 14 Prague 9, Klanovice,
   Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM alleculinnae.vn@centrum.cz
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Description;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Documentation;
   Publications; Land zones; Oriental region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Asia; China; India

AB A new genus and species, Sark-Inglis sariangi gen. nov., sp. nov., is
   described from Thailand. The taxonomical position of the genus within

AB Agathidium (Neoceble) aleseki sp. nov., A. (Agathidium) alesmetanai sp.
   nov., A. (A.) smetalesi sp., A. (A.) martinklanicai sp. nov., A. (A.)
   cheni sp. nov., A. (A.) grebennikovi sp. nov., A. (Macroceble) fui sp.
   nov., A. (Macr.) oui sp. nov., A. (Macro.) caoi sp. nov., A. (Mier.)
   janruzickai sp. nov., from China, Agathidi (Microceble) schmidti sp.
   nov. from Nepal, A. (A.) zhyneki sp. nov. from India, Dermatohomoeus
   schuelkei sp. n Colenisia castanea sp. nov. and C. schuelkei sp. nov.
   from China, are described and distinguished from similar species. The
   aedeagus of lesser known Chinese species Agathidium (Cyphoceble)
   wangianum Angelini, 2002; spermatheca of A. (A.) acutum Angelini, 2000
   and A. (A.) acuticorne Angelini, 2002 are figured for the first time.
   Agathidium (A.) acutum and A. (C.) wangianum from Sichuan, A. (A.)
   xianggangense Angelini & Cooter, 1999 A. (Neoceble) abbreviatum
   Angelini, 2002 from Yunnan, A. (A.) montanum Angelini & De Marzo, 1981
   from Nepal and Dermatohomoeus indicus Daffner, 1988 from Nepal are
   recorded for the first time.

AB A new species of Euconnus (Euconophron) alesi sp. nov. from China
   mainland (Fujian) is described and compared with another oriental
   species of the genus. Actually, the males of this new species also

DT Article
TI The West African species of Caenis Stephens (Insecta: Ephemeroptera).
AU Malzacher, Peter (malzacher.lb@t-online.de) 
SO Stuttgarter Beitraege zur Naturkunde Serie A (Biologie)
VL 4
PS 43-74
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present paper is the result of the examination of several thousand
   specimens of the genus Caenis Stephens, 1835 (Ephemeroptera) which were
   collected in West Africa in more than 200 light trap samples from 32
   rivers in Guinea, Mali, Ivory Coast, Togo and Ghana. Five new species
   are described: Caenis vermifera n. sp. (Ivory Coast, Guinea), C.
   nigricola n. sp. (Mali, Guinea), C. jinjanoides n. sp. (Guinea, Ivory
   Coast), C. kohli n. sp. (Guinea), and C. orthostilata n. sp. (Mali). The
   extensive materials allow to add distributional data to previously known
   species. C. elouardi, C. cibaria kunda, C. gilliesi, C. jinjana, C.
   antelucana, C. brevipes, C. berneri, and C. pallida are re-described.
   The eggs of most of the treated species are described based on SEM
   pictures. Several questions concerning supposed species relationships
   are discussed. The subspecies rank of C. brevipes occidentalis
   Malzacher, 1993 ist rejected.
C1 Malzacher, Peter; Friedrich Ebert Str 63, Ludwigsburg, Germany, Germany.
EM malzacher.lb@t-online.de
SC Zoology; Reproductive Biology
SN 0341-0145
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Taxonomy; Key;
   Reproduction; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
